Dilutive effect of stock options
Weighted Average Number Of Shares Outstanding Dilutive Effect Of Stock Options

Aggregate awards of share options issued to an employee under a share-based compensation arrangement are considered options for purposes of computing diluted earnings per share. Such share-based awards shall be considered to be outstanding as of the grant date for purposes of computing diluted earnings per share even though their exercise may be contingent upon vesting. Those share-based awards are included in the diluted Earnings Per Share (EPS) computation even if the employee may not receive (or be able to sell) the stock until some future date. Accordingly, all shares to be issued shall be included in computing diluted EPS if the effect is dilutive. The dilutive effect of share-based compensation arrangements shall be computed using the treasury stock method. If the equity share options or other equity instruments are outstanding for only part of a period, the shares issuable shall be weighted to reflect the portion of the period during which the equity instruments were outstanding.
Dilutive effect of retention shares and units
Weighted Average Number Of Shares Outstanding Dilutive Effect Of Retention Shares And Units

Aggregate awards of retention and performance retention shares issued to an employee under a share-based compensation arrangement are considered options for purposes of computing diluted earnings per share. Such share-based awards shall be considered to be outstanding as of the grant date for purposes of computing diluted earnings per share even though their exercise may be contingent upon vesting. Those share-based awards are included in the diluted Earnings Per Share (EPS) computation even if the employee may not receive (or be able to sell) the stock until some future date. Accordingly, all shares to be issued shall be included in computing diluted EPS if the effect is dilutive. The dilutive effect of share-based compensation arrangements shall be computed using the treasury stock method. If the equity share options or other equity instruments are outstanding for only part of a period, the shares issuable shall be weighted to reflect the portion of the period during which the equity instruments were outstanding.
Accrued casualty costs

Costs accrued as of the balance sheet date for casualty, environmental and other loss contingencies. Used to reflect the current portion of the liabilities (due within one year or within the normal operating cycle if longer).
Equipment rents payable

Costs accrued as of the balance sheet date for liabilities incurred (and for which invoices have typically been received) and payable to vendors for rent for freight cars owned by other railroads or private companies including lease expenses primarily for railcars, containers and trailers. Used to reflect the current portion of the liabilities (due within one year or within the normal operating cycle if longer).

Pension And Postretirement Benefits Policy [Text Block]

Describes an entity's accounting policy for its pension and other postretirement benefit plans. This disclosure may address (1) the types of plans sponsored by the entity, and the benefits provided by each plan (2) groups that participate in (or are covered by) each plan (3) how plan assets, liabilities and expenses are measured, including the use of any actuaries and (4) significant assumptions used by the entity to value plan assets and liabilities and how such assumptions are derived.
Personal Injury Policy [Text Block]
Describes an entity's accounting policies for individual claims alleging that the company was responsible for the individual's injury.
Asbestos Policy [Text Block]
Describes an entity's accounting policies for individual or consolidated class action claims alleging that asbestos caused cancer to persons exposed to it.
Environmental Policy [Text Block]

Describes an entity's accounting policy for obligations that resulted from improper or other-than normal operation of a long-lived asset in the past. This accounting policy may address (1) whether the related remediation costs are expensed or capitalized, (2) whether the obligation is measured on a discounted basis, (3) the event, situation, or set of circumstances that generally triggers recognition of loss contingencies arising from the entity's environmental remediation-related obligations, and (4) the timing of recognition of any recoveries.

Pension Qualified Plan [Member]

The plan is a defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all non-agreement employees of Union Pacific Corporation and certain affiliates. This plan meets the requirements of Internal Revenue Code and is eligible for favorable tax treatment.
Pension Non-qualified Plan [Member]

The plan is a defined benefit pension plan covering Officers and Managers of Union Pacific Corporation and Affiliates. This plan does not meet the requirements of Internal Revenue Code and is not eligible for favorable tax treatment.

an intermediate to long-term security that pays a fixed return based on payments received from the lease of the equipment. Holders of the debt receive lease payments until the obligation matures at which point ownership of the assets is transferred to the leasing company.
Tax-Exempt Financings [Member]

municipal bonds issued to raise capital for improvements in infrastructure or other aspects of the municipality. The bonds are exempt from federal income taxes and therefore usually carry lower interest rates than corporate bonds.
Floating Rate Term Loan [Member]
a fixed-term business loan with an interest rate that changes on a periodic basis. The change is tied to the movement of an outside indicator, such as a market accepted interest rate index.

Personal Injury [Member]
Individual claims alleging that the company was responsible for the individual's injury that requires reserves to be provided for related medical claims and punitive damages.
Significant New Borrowings [Abstract]
Depreciation rate

Rate used to depreciate properties and equipment on a straight-line basis over their estimated service lives, which are measured in years, except for rail in high-density traffic corridors (i.e., all rail lines except for those subject to abandonment, yard and switching tracks, and electronic yards), for which lives are measured in millions of gross tons per mile of track. We use the group method of depreciation in which all items with similar characteristics, use, and expected life are grouped together in asset classes, and are depreciated using composite depreciation rates. The group method of depreciation treats each asset class as a pool of resources, not as singular items. We determine the estimated service lives of depreciable railroad assets by means of depreciation studies. Under the group method of depreciation, no gain or loss is recognized when depreciable property is retired or replaced in the ordinary course of business.
PropertyPlantAndEquipmentTotalCost
Total cost
PropertyplantAndEquipmentTotalAccumulatedDepreciation
Total accumulated depreciation
Accumulated depreciation of property and equipment.
Roadrail And Other Track Material Member [Member]

The cost of rails and other track material used in the construction of tracks for the movement or storage of locomotives and cars (including tracks in shops, fuel stations, supply yard areas, etc.); the cost of welding two or more lengths or rail into continuous lengths for use in construction of tracks; and the cost of labor associated with unloading and installation of the rail and other track material.
Road: Rail and Other Track Material [Member]
Road: Ties [Member]

The cost of cross, switch, bridge and other track ties used in the construction of tracks for the movement or storage of locomotives and cars (including tracks in shops, fuel stations, supply yard areas, etc.), and the cost of additional ties subsequently laid in such tracks. It also includes the cost of labor for unloading, distributing and placing ties in tracks.
Road: Ballast [Member]

The cost of gravel, stone, slag, cinders, sand, and like material used in ballasting tracks (including tracks in shops, fuel stations, and supply yard areas, etc.), including cost of worktrain service and the cost of labor expended in placing ballast in tracks.
Road: Other [Member]
The cost of all other road property owned by the carrier and devoted to transportation service other than rail and other track material, ties, and ballast.
Total Road [Member]
Total cost of road property owned by the carrier and devoted to transportation service.
Equipment: Locomotives [Member]

The cost of locomotives purchased or built by the carrier, and of appurtenances, furniture, and fixtures necessary to equip them for service, including the cost of inspection, setting up, and trying out after receipt from builders, and transportation charges to the carrier's line.
Equipment: Freight Cars [Member]

The cost of freight-train cars of all classes purchased or built by the carrier, including all appurtenances, furniture, and fixtures necessary to equip them for service, and the cost of inspection and transportation charges to the carrier's line.
Equipment: Work Equipment and Other [Member]

The cost of work equipment, including motor-driven equipment, purchased or built by the carrier; cost of highway vehicles used in revenue transportation service, including pickup and delivery service, substitute line-haul service, and TOFC/COFC service; and the cost of automobiles, trucks and other highway equipment not used in revenue transportation service and not provided for elsewhere; the cost of airplanes; cost of appurtenances, furniture, and fixtures necessary to equip it for service; and cost of inspection and transportation charges to the carrier's line.
Total Equipment [Member]

The cost of the several classes of equipment vehicles and shop and power plant equipment owned by the carrier, or held under equipment trust agreements or other contractual obligation for purchase of the property.
